Anwar is the mother of four sons.  Her elder son drives a donkey cart.  The other two have a burger point in the food market.  Her youngest son is in kindergarten.  

Anwar operates a sewing clothes business.  She takes orders from her neighbors and relatives and charges them $2 for simple stitching and $3 for designer clothes.  Anwar saves her income and wants to marry off her eldest son with the committee amount.  

She successfully repaid her four loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy animals (buffalos) for her husband’s animal selling business. 

Anwar is the group leader of three another women from her locality. Hajra wants a loan to buy scrap for her business.  Kalsoom wants a loan to buy groceries for her shop.  Nagina wants a loan to buy clothes for her business. 

This is a group loan.  The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business.  The members mutually guarantee one another's loans.  If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Buy buffalos for animal selling business.

loans.name: Soo

texts.en:
Soo P., 69, is widowed with seven children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. Soo sells to village people and the general public three days a week.

She has five previous loans with SPBD. Soo expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about $145). South Pacific Business Development loans are Soo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for home improvements.

loans.use: Support plantation business and help improve home.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie T., 25, is married with one child. She has many years of experience in the planatation business. Annie sells to village people and the general public three days per week.

She has no previous loans with South Pacific Business Development. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD). SPBD loans are Annie’s only access to capital because she is not able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase items to support plantation business.

loans.name: Salma M.riaz Group

texts.en:
Salma is a wife of M. who lives in a city named Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan.  Her husband runs a garment shop in the cloth market.  People come to him to buy garments because he has a good collection with new designs.  He has been in this profession for the past seven years. 

Salma is a housewife but she keeps herself busy knitting clothes.  Her activity gives her rewards in the shape of money.  She knits sofa sets and table covers and sells in the markets.  

Salma successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now she is applying for a loan to buy garments for her husband’s business.
 
She is the group leader of four another women from her locality.  Hanifan wants a loan to buy shoes to sell.  Nasreen wants a loan to buy scrap for her business.  Asia wants a loan to pay the remaining installments of her auto-rickshaw (three-wheeled motor vehicle).  Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her cloth selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Buy garments to sell for husband's business.

loans.name: Suisami

texts.en:
Suisami A., 42, is married with 4 children. She has 4 years of experience planting taro, yams, and bananas. She sells to the village people and general public 3 days a week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD).

She has no previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Suisami’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals and supplies for her farm

loans.name: Lusia

texts.en:
Lusia T., 39, is married with 4 children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and general public 3 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

She has no previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Lusia’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Buy pesticides and supplies for her farm

loans.name: Restituta

texts.es:
La Sra. Restituta J. nació en la ciudad de Capiata el 09 de diciembre del año 1962. Vive desde hace mas de diez años con Emiliano Reyes Acosta.  Ella tiene una hija llamada Andrea de 20 años de edad quien esta estudiando la carrera de obstetricia y a la vez prestando servicios en el Hospital Materno Infantil de Capiata. El Sr. Emiliano trabaja como guardia de seguridad en el horario nocturno mientras la Sra. Restituta tiene una muy surtida despensa en su domicilio. 

Opera con la Fundación Paraguaya desde el año 2002 accediendo a créditos que facilitan el aumento de su inventario y asi obtener un mayor ingreso familiar a traves del comercio de productos comestibles, a granel bebidas entre otras mercaderías como tambien cubrir los gastos escolares de su hija.
texts.en:
Mrs. Restituta J. was born in the city of Capiata on December 9 of 1962. She has been living with Emiliano Reyes Acosta for more than ten years. She has a daughter, Andrea, who is 20 years old and studying to be an obstetrician and at the same time working at Hospital Materno Infantil of Capiata. Mr. Emiliano works as a security guard during the nights, meanwhile Mrs. Restituta has a well stocked store in her residence. She has been with the Fundacion Paraguayana since 2002 obtaining loans which help her to increase her inventory and improve her family income through the sale of edible products, beverages in bulk among other merchandise. This way she can also cover her daughter's educational expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of edible products, and merchadise in bulk for her general store.

loans.name: Sajida Sajjad Hussain Group

texts.en:
Sajida baji is a 27-year-old married lady and a citizen of a city named Kot Radha Kishan for the last 8 years. Her husband's name is S. H., and he is a mason by profession. He constructs buildings under the guidance of a building constructor and earns half of the family's income.

Sajida baji is a very hardworking woman. She gets up at 4:00 a.m. to milk their buffalo. After that, she sells the buffalo milk to the milk shops. She does this work to meet the financial expenses of her household. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a micro finance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy masonry tools for her husband.

She is the group leader of four other women from her area. Nasreen baji and Nasreen baji each want a loan to buy bricks to sell. Gulistan baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee each others loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Buy masonry tools

loans.name: Arca De Noe Group

texts.es:
El Grupo Arca de Noe son mujeres responsables con deseos de salir adelante, tambien son vecinas cercanas con mucha experiencia en sus actividades diarias, este grupo se identifica de esta forma:
La Sra. Lucrecia tiene 56 años de edad, tiene 15 años de dedicarse a su negocio que es la venta de condimentos, ella se lavanta temprano para preparar las ristras de especias, pimienta olorosa, consome, saborina, sal de ajo, sal de cebolla, azafran, canela, curry, linaza, ya que este producto lo vende en diferentes pueblos cercanos a la ciudad capital como ser Talanga, Catacamas, Tatumbla, ya que ella surte a pulperas de estos lugares, su producto es muy bien vendido. su meta para este año es poder distribuir su producto en otas aldeas o pueblos.
La Sra. Yolanda tiene 55 años de edad, es madre soltera, de ella depende su hijo al 100% ya que toda via le esta pagando los estudios. ella vende zapatos para dama, niños, boxers, calcetas, camisetas, manteles, cameras, ella tiene muchos clientes fijos que le van a comprar todos los meses a su casa de habitacion, los clientes la prefieren porque ella es muy amable con ellos y les da buenos precios cuando son clientes recurrentes., ella necesita el credito para comprar mas ropa, cortinas, carteras, sandalias, el sueño de ella es tener una tienda de variedades en la cual pueda vender muchos productos.
la Sra. Blanca tiene 40 años de edad, tiene 15 años de dedicarse a su taller de costura, ella confecciona prendas de vestir como ser: pantalones, faldas, camisas, tambien ella tiene una minipulperia, ella necesita el credito para comprar productos para la pulperia como ser: mantequilla, queso, carnes, y asi mejorar la calidad de su negocio, es madre soltera y tiene dos hijas las cuales estan estudiando.
texts.en:
The Arca de Noe (Noah's Ark) loan group are three responsible women who want to get ahead. They are also close neighbors who have lots of experience in their daily activities. Here is a description of this group: Señora Lucrecia is 56 years of age and has been engaged for 15 years in the business of selling condiments. She gets up early to prepare the line of spices (fragrant pepper, consomme, savory, garlic salt, onion salt, saffron, cinnamon, curry, linseed) which she sells in Talanga, Catacamas, Tatumbla and other towns in the vicinity of the capital city. Since she supplies the storekeepers in these places, her products are selling well. Her goal this year is to be able to distribute her products in other towns and villages. Señora Yolanda is 55 years of age and a single mother. Her son is completely dependent on her since she is still paying for his education. She sells shoes for women and children, underwear, socks, t-shirts, tablecloths and bedspreads. She has many established customers who come each month to buy from her at her house. Her customers like her because she is very pleasant with them and gives good prices to returning customers. She needs this loan in order to buy more clothing, curtains, handbags and sandals. Her dream is to have a variety store from which she could sell lots of merchandise. Señora Blanca is 40 years of age. She has dedicated the last 15 years to her sewing shop. She produces articles of clothing, such as slacks, skirts and blouses. She also has a mini-mart and she needs this loan to buy products for this store, such as butter, cheese and meats, and to improve the quality of her business. She is a single mother with two daughters who are still in school.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients, dry goods, and groceries

loans.name: Leonor

texts.es: El señor Leonor C. nació en Luque en el año 1937, vive con la Sra. Victoriana Ferreira Romero  desde hace mas de 30 años. Don Leonor tiene una despensa en su domicilio ubicado en el tercer barrio de Luque. Opera con la Fundación Paraguaya desde el año 1997. Ambas personas dirigen el negocio ya que no tienen hijos menores y los recursos financieros lo destinan normalmente para mejorar su local comercial y comprar artículos comestibles, a granel y mercerias varias a fin de aumentar su inventario y poder asi mejorar su ingreso familiar a traves del comercio al por menor.
texts.en:
Leonor C. was born in Luque in 1937; he has lived with Victoriana Ferreira Romero for more than 30 years. Leonor has a grocery store in his home located in the third neighborhood in Luque. He has been working with the Paraguaya Foundation since 1997. Both Leonor and Victoriana run the business given that they do not have young children. Their financial resources are usually destined for improvements to their commercial locale and for the purchase of food items in bulk and assorted merchandise, with aim of increasing their inventory to be able to improve the family’s income through retail commerce.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase vegetables, drinks, food items, and general merchandise.

loans.name: Ropati

texts.en: Ropati A., 24, is single.  She has many year(s) of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and general puplic 3 days per week. She has no previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Ropati’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks

loans.use: Purchase weed killer , gromozones, barred wire and nails

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria, 26, is married with two children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public/villagers 3 days per week. This is Maria's first loan with SPBD, and she will use it to purchase a water hose, pesticides, herbicides, and bush knives for use on the plantation.

SPBD loans are Maria’s only access to capital because she has been unable to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala ($145 USD).

loans.use: Purchase water hose, gromozones, pesticides, weedkiller, and bushknives.

loans.name: Zarina M. Ashiq Group

texts.en:
Zarina is the group bank leader of four women from her locality. She is the mother of four kids: three sons and one daughter. None of her children go to school. Her husband is in the bread making business. They have lived in the city of Kot Radha Kishan for the last 16 years.
Zarina operates a tailoring business. Her daughter helps her in the cutting of dresses. She has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy flour for her husband’s bread making business. 
The other members of the group will use the loan as follows: Gaman sells milk and will use her portion of the loan to buy a buffalo for her milk business. Sheema and Tanveer each want to buy a buffalo for their animal sales businesses. Sakina will use the loan to buy cosmetics to resell. 
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy flour for bread making & selling business

loans.name: Las Luchadoras Group

texts.es:
El grupo las luchadoras son mujeres que se llevan muy bien y son muy responsables con muchos deseos de superarse, son vecinas cercanas. este grupo se define de la siguiente forma:
Doña Martha R. tiene 18 meses de tener su propia pulperia, este negocio esta ubicado en un lugar muy estrategico donde tiene mucha demanda, de ella depende su hijo de 2 años y asi estando en su negocio no descuida su hijo,  ella en las noches trabaja cuidando a un señor ya que ella estudia enfermeria los dias sabados, la cliente necesita el credito para comprar una maquina industrial en forma de plancha para hacer tortas de carnes para hamburguesas. este negocio lo quiere hacer para los dias sabados en la noche y todo el domingo, su sueño es poder graduarse de enfermera, asi poder tener un trabajo fijo los dias de semana y los fines de semana dedicarse a s negocio.
La Sra. Gabriela R. se dedica a la venta de tortillas, elle tiene 1 año de tener su negocio, ella es una persona muy agradable, la mayoria de su producto lo entrega en una pollera y la otra parte la vende en la casa, ella vive con su mama, en las noches ella cuida a su hermano, ella necesita el credito para comprar leña, maseca, agua, cal para hacer mas tortillas y tambien necesita comprar perlas, estaño hilos, porque ella hace collares y pulseras.
Doña Maria tiene 30 años de edad, su negocio tiene 4 años de tenerlo, ella vende ropa como ser camisas, blusas, pantalones, calcetines, boxers, tambien vende vasos, tasas, platos, zapatos peluches. ella necesita el credito ahora para comprar un fardo de ropa y asi poder tener mas ganancias, ya que ahora las esta comprando por libras la ropa y sale mas caro, y este negocio es muy bueno , por tal razon necesita el credito asi compra el fardo de ropa y le sale mucho mas barato y puede tener muchas ganancias.
texts.en:
"Las Luchadoras" are a group of women that are friends. They are very responsible and have a lot of will to get ahead. They are close neighbors that consist of the following people:

Mrs. Martha R. has had her own grocery store for 18 months. Her business is in a very strategic location where there is a lot of demand. Her 2 years old son depends of her, and this business allows her to take care of him herself. At night, she works as a caretaker for a gentleman since she is studying on Saturdays to become a nurse. Our client needs a loan to buy an industrial press to make hamburgers. She wants to start doing this on Saturday nights and Sundays all day. Her dream is to graduate as a nurse; this way she will be able to have a permanent job during the week, and she can dedicate herself to her business in the weekends.

Mrs. Gabriela R. sells tortillas. She has had her business for 1 year. She is a friendly person, and sell the majority of her products to a chicken restaurant, while the rest is sold from her home. She lives with her mother, and at night takes care of her brother. She needs a loan to buy firewood, tortilla flour, water, and quicklime to make tortillas. In addition, she wants to buy pearls and metal wire because she also makes necklaces and bracelets.

Mrs. Maria is 30 years old, and she has had her business for 4 years. She sells clothing like shirts, blouses, pants, socks, and boxer shorts, but also glasses, cups, plates, shoes, and soft toys. She now needs a loan to buy a bundle of clothes to increase her profit margin, since she has been buying clothes by the pound at higher prices. This is a good business and therefore she needs the loan to buy a bundle of clothes which is a lot cheaper and brings her more profit.

Translated from Spanish by Ramon Kolb, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an industrial press, potatoes, meat, pearls, steel, tortilla flower, firewood, and plastic bags.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria I., 38, is married with six children.  She has six years of experience in planting taro, yams and bananas. She sells to the village people and the general public three days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about $145).  SPBD loans are Maria’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for home improvement.

loans.use: Purchase weed killer, timber, water hose, wheelbarrow, spade, bushknives, iron roofing and cement

loans.name: Cristeta

texts.es:
La Señora Cristeta O. de 54 años de edad es separada, tiene cinco hijos, de los cuales cuatro son independientes, y el menor de once años está cursando el 7mo. Grado escolar; éste es su mano derecha en el negocio.

En tiempos anteriores, Cristeta era dependiente de un importante centro comercial. Un día cuando se trasladaba a su lugar de trabajo fué victima de un accidente de tránsito. Ella quedo con secuelas físicas del percance, siendo beneficiada con una pequeña pensión por accidente. Así, como buena emprendedora que és, inicia esta actividad comercial en su domicilio con el apoyo de sus hijos. 

El objetivo de este crédito es aprovechar la oportunidad de contar con un mayor volúmen de mercaderías, atendiendo al momento del inicio de clases en las instituciones educativas.
texts.en:
Cristeta O. is 54 years old, separated, and has 5 children, four of whom are independent, and the youngest who is eleven years old is in the 7th grade; the youngest is the right hand of the business. Previously, Cristeta had been dependent on an important mall where she worked. One day while she was on the way to her place of employment she was a victim of a car accident. She was left with physical injuries due to the accident, and was given small settlement as a result. Because she is an enterprising woman, she began this commercial activity in her home with the support of her children. The objective of this loan is to take advantage of the opportunity to acquire more merchandise, paying attention to the beginning of classes in the educational institutions.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase Yerba Mate, soft drinks, mineral water, natural juices, various sweets, etc.

loans.name: Riffat Rasheed Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Riffat baji is a 38-year-old married lady who has lived in a city named Kot Radha Kishan for the past 18 years. Her husband, R. A., has a brick-selling business. He has been in this profession for the past 5 years. Riffat baji is the mother of six kids: three sons and three daughters. None of her children go to school. Riffat baji makes and embroiders dresses to order and earns income. Her elder daughter helps her make embroidered dresses. She successfully repaid her past three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to expand her husband’s brick-selling business.

She is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Maqbool baji, Razia baji and Rashida baji each want a loan to buy bricks to sell. Rasoolan baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her animal-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy bricks to sell

loans.name: Branda Yamileth

texts.es:
La Sra. Brenda C. tiene 38 años de edad es soltera y tiene un hijo de 12 años de edad, el esta cursando el sexto grado de educacion primaria, el lo es todo para ella, es por quien ella vive y trabaja. 
ella posee una pulperia desde hace 10 años, le ha ido muy bien, este negocio es muy prospero y necesita el credito para poder surtilo mas y asi tener una mejor variedad para sus clientes, su sueño es tener un super mercado y asi como ella va creo que en poco tiempo lo va a lograr.
texts.en:
Mrs. Brenda C. is 38 years old. She is single, with a 12 year old son who is in sixth grade. Her son is very important to her and gives her the motivation and incentive to keep living and working hard. She has run a general store for 10 years and the business is very good. She is requesting a loan to grow her business with more variety of goods for her clients. Her dream is to eventually have a super market. Her dedication to the business will help her achieve her goals soon.

Translated from Spanish by Zoe Mullard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of drinks, sweets, chicken, beef, pork, sardines (tins), toothpase, toilet paper, workbooks, beans, sugar, rice and butter

loans.name: Isapela

texts.en: Isapela, 37, is married and has three children. She has five years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and general public three days a week. This is her first loan with SPBD. She will use the loan to buy supplies such as pesticides, gromozones, taro tubes, and bush knives. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about $145 USD).  SPBD loans are Isapela’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks

loans.use: Buy pesticides, gromozones, taro tubes, and bush knives

loans.name: Selesitina

texts.en:
Selesitina F. is married with four children. She has four years of experience in the plantation/vegetable business. She sells to village people and the general public three days per week.

Selesitina has three previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).

SPBD loans are Selesitina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for home improvement.

loans.use: Purchase farm supplies and repair her home.

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es: La Sra. Maritza C. Z. tiene 46 años de edad, ella vive en la colonia Morazan, tiene un hijo de 12 años de edad, es soltera y se dedica a la venta de golosinas como ser: tacos, enchiladas, tortilas con quesillo, burritas, baleadas, los domingos hace sopa de mondongo y sopa de pescado, ella tiene 15 años de tener su negocio, dicho negocio lo tiene en su casa de habitacion, su deseo es remodelar su casa y poder hacer un comedor mas grande en el cual puedan llegar muchos clientes, esta es su unica fuente de ingresos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maritza C. Z. is 46 years old, she lives in the Morazan district, has a 12-year-old son, is a single mother and sells snacks such as tacos, enchiladas, cheese tortillas, burritos, and baleadas. On Sundays she makes tripe soup and fish soup. She has had her business for 15 years, and carries on said business in a room in her home. She hopes to remodel her house to make the dining room larger so that she will be able to attend to more clients, this is her only means of income.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Kirkvold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of vegetables, meats, tortillas, cheese, butter, beverages, plates, cups, coffee, and biscuits

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Laumua

texts.en:
Laumua S. is married with six children. She has many years of experience planting bananas and taro. Laumua sells to village people and the general public three days per week.

She has five previous loans with SPBD. Laumua expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

SPBD loans are Laumua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used to pay her kids' school fees and for home improvement.

loans.use: Puchase farm supplies and pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Susitina

texts.en:
Susitina, 36, is married and has three children.  She has two yeas of experience in elei printing and fabric paints. Elei is the art of drawing patterns on a plate and then cutting it into shapes. It is then attached to the fabric and painted over with different colors.

Susitina sells to the public five days a week. This is her first loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 83 Tala. SPBD loans are Susitina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Susitina is a new member, she just joined SPBD with the initiative to start up her elei business.

loans.use: Purchase elei board, brushes, color painting and materials

loans.name: Juana Guadalupe

texts.es: la Sra. Maritza N. P. tiene 28 años de edad, ella vive en union libre con su compañero de hogar el Sr. Thomas Guevara quien labora en la alcaldia de San Lorenzo, ellos tienen un hijo de 10 años de edad quien esta en la escuela. ella se dedica a la venta de ropa, tiene 10 años de vender su producto, ella necesita comprar un fardo de ropa porque el que compro la vez anterior le salio ropa que no vendio mucho y se quedo con mucho producto, es que le dieron el equivocado y no lo pudo devolver, asi que ahora necesita comprar uno nuevo.
texts.en:
Maritza N. P. is 28 years old and lives with her common-law husband Thomas Guevara who works in the mayor's office in San Lorenzo. They have a 10 year-old son that is a student. She has been working for 10 years selling clothing. She needs to buy a bundle of clothing because the one that she previously bought contained a lot of clothing that didn't sell and so she was left with a lot of merchandise; she was sent the wrong bundle type and couldn't return it so that's why she needs to buy a new bundle now.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bundles of clothing to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Feagaiga

texts.en:
Feagaiga M., 32, is married and has six children.  She has five years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public  3 or 4 days per week. This is her first loan with SPBD. She will use the loan to buy supplies such as bushknives, knife sharpener, digger, spade, axe, gromozones, stings, fertilizer, and weedkiller. 

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 104 Tala. SPBD loans are Feagaiga’s only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase bushknives, knife sharpener, digger, spade, axe, gromozones, stings, fertilizer, and weedkiller.

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.es:
El inicio del presente comité fue la señora Carmen I., quien ya habria pertenecido a un comite de las misma zona junto con otra personas se retiraron por cuestiones personales, invitaron y organizaron a sus amigas para formar otro comité y asi ser parte del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.

La señora Patricia Mendoza es peluquera, invirtió el dinero en la compra de materiales para su trabajo de ese modo ofrecer mayo comodidad a sus clientes.

La señora Porfiria Martinez  se dedica a la venta de comestible, invirtió el dinero en la compra mercaderia para la elaboracion de los comestibles de manera a ofrecer calidad y variedad de comestible a la clientela.

La señora Carmen I. se dedica a la venta de Lencería, invirtió el dinero en la compra de esas mercaderías pudiendo ofrecer  mayor variedad de prendas a sus clientes

La señora Limpia N. se dedica a la venta de producto de limpieza, invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumo para la elaboracion de detergentes, lavandina, suavizante de ropa

La señora Justa Ruiz se dedica a la ventra de comestible, invirtió su dinero en la compra de mercaderías para la elaboracion de los comestibles pudiendo asi ofrever mayor variendad a sus clientes.

La señora Agustina G. se dedica a la venta de chipa, invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías para la elaboracion de las chipas logrando asi mantener la calidad de sus comestibles.

La señora Francisca C.  tiene una despensa,  invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías variadas y seguir surtiendo con nuevas mercaderías su despensa.

La señora Agueda S.  se dedica a la venta de comestible,invirtió el dinero en la compra de elementos( ollas, paila,ect.) para la elaboracion de   los comestibles.

La señora Dora A. se dedica a la venta de comestibles, invirtrio el dinero en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboracion de los comestibles ofrecer de esa manera calidad a sus clientes.

La señora Marilina M. es peluquera,  invirtió el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo en la peluquerias pudiendo ofrecer un buen servicio a sus clientes.

La señora Emilia L. es peluquera, invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumo para su peluqueria asegurando la comodidas de sus clientes.

La señora Modesta Benítez  se dedica a la artesania, invirtió el dinero en la compra de elementos para la elaboracion de cuadros, articulos de bijuoteri, ect. Pudiendo ofrecer mayor variedad.

La señora Lidia Vázquez tiene un copetin, invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías varias azucar, yerba, lacteos, bebidas, panificados para surtir su negocio y ofrecer mayor variedad a sus clientela.

La señora Sergia Fernadez se dedica a la venta de comestible y bebidas, invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías para elaboracion de los comestibles y compra al por mayor de bebidas pudiendo asi ofrecer calidad y variedad a sus clientes.

La señora Nina Q. se dedica a la venta de Lencería, invirtió el  dinero en la compra de esas prendas al por mayor para luego reenvenderlas obteniendo asi mayor variedad en sus mercaderías y mayor ingreso.

 La señora Diana G. se dedica a la venta de ropa, invirtió el dinero en la compra de prendas en general pudiendo asi surtir su mercaderia y ofrecer mas variedad a sus clientes.

La señoraNilda C. se dedica a la venta de cosmetoligia, invirtió el dinero en la compra de cosmeticos y elementos para la su venta
texts.en:
Mrs. Carmen I. started our current group. She had already belonged to a group in the same area with other people who left the group for personal reasons. Carmen invited and organized her friends to form another group. That’s how we became the Group of Enterprising Women. Mrs. Patricia Mendoza is a hair dresser. She will buy supplies for her work to make her customers more comfortable. Mrs. Porfiria Martinez sells food. She will buy items for preparing her food in order to provide her customers with quality and variety. Mrs. Carmen I. sells lingerie. She will buy merchandise to be able to offer a larger selection of items for her customers. Mrs. Limpia N. sells cleaning products. She will buy supplies to produce detergents, bleach, and fabric softener. Mrs. Justa Ruiz sells food. She will buy items to make food to be able to offer a bigger variety to her customers. Mrs. Agustina G. sells “chipa”, typical bread in Paraguay. She will buy supplies to make her bread, and that allows her to maintain the quality of her food. Mrs. Francisca C. has a store. She will buy a variety of merchandise and continue to stock up on new merchandise for the store. Mrs. Agueda S. sells food. She will buy pots and pans to use to make food. Mrs. Dora A. sells food. She will buy ingredients to make the food and offer quality food to her customers. Mrs. Marilina M. is a hairdresser. She will buy things for her work in the beauty parlor in order to provide her customers with good service. Mrs. Emilia L. is a hairdresser. She will buy supplies for her work that will provide her customers many comforts. Mrs. Modesta Benítez works with crafts. She will buy supplies to make a variety of pictures and accessories. Mrs. Lidia Vásquez has a café. She will stock her business with various types of merchandise, such as sugar, herbs, milk products, drinks, and flour, in order to offer a variety of products to her customers. Mrs. Sergia F. sells food and drinks. She will buy supplies to make food. She will also buy wholesale drinks which will allow her to offer quality and variety to her customers. Mrs. Nina Q. sells lingerie. She will buy wholesale items for resale. This way she will obtain a greater variety of merchandise, and she will increase her income. Mrs. Diana G. sells clothes. She will buy general clothing items to increase her stock and provide more variety for her customers. Mrs. Nilda Cardoza sells cosmetology products. She will buy cosmetics and other items to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy general clothing items, items for hairdressing,eggs, flour, dairy products, drinks, meat, sausages, corn, breads, canned goods, herbs, oil, sweets, vegetables, fruits,  etc.

loans.name: Selepa

texts.en:
Selepa F., 39, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in the Cocoa business. She sells to villagers and the public five days per week.

She has 4 previous loan(s) with SPBD. Selepa expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD). SPBD loans are Selepa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. Her husband helps out with the production of her ground cocoa.

loans.use: Purchase equipment needed for improving her business.

loans.name: Linda Rosa

texts.es: la Sra. Linda Rosa G. tiene 50 años de edad, es casada y tiene 5 hijos de los cuales ninguno esta con ella porque ya se casaron y viven con su pareja, ella se dedica a la venta de carne de cerdo, hamacas, pantalones y quesillo, ella tiene 40 años de dedicarse a este tipo de actividad, ella vive en la aldea de jicaro galan y es reconocida como una persona muy luchadora, ella necesita el credito porque tiene que comprar las hamacas al por mayor ya que le salen muy caras comprarlas por cantidades pequeñas, y ella tiene que viajar para ir a comprarlas entoces no puede estar viajando a cada rato y comprando el producto caro, por tal razon necesita el credito.
texts.en:
Linda Rosa G. is 50 years old, married, and has five children, all of whom are married and live with their spouses. She sells pork, hammocks, pants and flan. She has spent 40 years doing this type of work. She lives in the village of Jicaro Galan and is known as a fighter. She needs the loan to purchase wholesale hammocks, as it is very expensive to buy them in small quantities. Also, she must travel to buy them, and she cannot travel all the time to buy the expensive products, so this is why she needs the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase hammocks, pork, pants and flan

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Delvy Marina

texts.es:
La Sra. Delvy G. tiene 43 años de edad, vive en union libre con su compañero de hogar y tienen un hijo, el cual los dos lo estan educando para que sea un hombre de valores.
ella se dedica a la venta de ropa como ser: pantalones, camisas, blusas, trajes para niños, calsonetas, blumers, braciers. cobijas, cortinas y calsetas, tiene 20 años de dedicarse a este negocio con el cual le ha ayudado a mantener su hogar, ella necesita el credito ya que ella viaja para comprar esta mercaderia y necesita comprar varios purductos para tener en existencia y asi no gastar dinero en viajes.
texts.en:
Delvy G. is 43 years old and lives with her common law husband, with whom she has a son. The two of them are educating their son so he will become a man of values. Delvy sells clothing like pants, shirts, blouses, boys' suits, shorts, underwear, bras, blankets, curtains and stockings. She has been working in this business for 20 years, and it has allowed her to maintain her home. She needs this loan because she travels to buy her merchandise, and she needs to buy various products to stay afloat and not waste money traveling.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase men's and women's clothing

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Olga Leticia

texts.es: la Sra. Olga F. se dedica a la venta de pescado frito y tambien hace sopas de pescado, su fuerte es el pescado frito pero tambien hace cocteles de curiles, camarones, sopas marineras, ella tiene muchos años de dedicarse a esta actividad, la cual es muy buena porque a la gente le encanta comer pescado frito y como ahorita se aproxima la Semana Santa ella desea comprar muchos mariscos ya que los clientes son muchos y no se va a dar abasto con el producto que tiene, quiere estar preparada para esta epoca que es dentro de semana y media.
texts.en:
Olga F. sells fried fish and also makes fish soups. Her specialty is fried fish, but she also makes clam cocktail, shrimp and seafood soups. She has worked in this business for many years, and this has gone very well very well because people love to eat fried fish. With the Holy Week coming up, she wants to buy a lot of seafood because there will be a lot of customers and she does not yet have a sufficient supply. She wants to be prepared for this occasion, which is in a week and a half.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fish, oil, butter, salt, vegetables, cabbage, onions, vinegar, spices, tortillas, soft drinks

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sosefina

texts.en: Sosefina T. S., 38, is married and has 4 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public two days a week. This is her first loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about $145 USD). SPBD loans are Sosefina’s only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.Sosefina use her loan to buy tools and chemical for her business also her home improvement.

loans.use: Purchases to buy some tool to use for planting taro &taamu also chemical to killed inset.

loans.name: Keli

texts.en:
Keli S., 52, is married with three children. She has many years of experience in the taro, banana business. She sells to villagers and general public three days per week.

She has one previous loan with SPBD. Keli expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Keli’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase equipment needed for improve her business.

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en:
Akenese E., 30, is married with two children. She has many years of experience in the fresh fish business. She sells to the villagers and the public five days per week.

She has had two previous loans with Kiva's partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (about $125). SPBD loans are Akenese’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

Ake's loan will be used to buy fishing equipment and some part of the loan will be spent on paying her children's school fees.

loans.use: Purchase fishing equipment and pay school fees

loans.name: Juanita Nayiri

texts.es:
En el mercado Central de la ciudad de León, la señora Juanita Láinez posee un pequeño negocio de alquiler de videojuegos el cual es visitada por varios niños y jóvenes que hacen uso del servicio.

La razón por la que ella ha acudido a Ceprodel es solicitar un crédito para la compra de los videojuegos y así continuar con su negocio que tanto requiere de inversión por ser muy popular en su localidad.
texts.en:
In the central market of the city of Leon, Mrs. Juanita L. has a small video game rental business which is frequented by children and young people who use her services. The reason for her turning to Ceprodel and requesting the loan is to be able to purchase video games and thus continuing her business which needs the investment since it is very popular in the area.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of video games

loans.name: Xiomara De Jesús

texts.es:
Xiomara O. es una dama que con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado establecer su negocio de venta de electrodomésticos en el mercado Central de la ciudad de León donde a diario comercializa sus productos con el propósito de salir adelante y mantener su hogar.

Hoy en día ha buscado el apoyo en Ceprodel para obtener un crédito para la compra de los electrodomésticos y por eso espera muy confiadamente sabiendo que su crédito será otorgado y así saldrá adelante en su negocio. Actualmente ella posee un record crediticio de 44 créditos habiéndolos cancelado todos satisfactoriamente en tiempo y forma de acuerdo a lo establecido.
texts.en:
Xiomara O. is a lady who through a lot of hard work has been able to establish her small appliance sales business in the central market of the city of Leon, where she sells her products daily with the goal of getting ahead and supporting her home. Currently she has come to Ceprodel to obtain a loan for the purchase of small appliances. She is confidently waiting for her loan to be approved and being able to get ahead in her business. She has a credit history of 44 loans, all of which were appropiately paid off in time and in accordance with the loan agreements.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase small appliances for resale.

loans.name: Jahaira De Los Angeles

texts.es:
En la ciudad de León del bello país de Nicaragua, la señora Jahaira M. se dedica a su negocio de venta de joyas comercializadas a diario con el propósito de mantener su hogar compuesto por sus dos pequeños hijos que se dedican a estudiar y por ende debe sufragar sus gastos.

La razón por la cual ella ha acudido a Ceprodel hoy en día es para solicitar un crédito para la compra de las joyas y así continuar comercializándolas en su sector.
texts.en:
In the city of Leon of the beautiful country of Nicaragua, Mrs. Jahaira Munillo daily dedicates her time to her business of selling jewelry with the goal of supporting her home which is made up of two small children who are in school and need her help. Her reason for coming to Ceprodel this time is to request a loan with which she will purchase jewelry that she will resell in her area.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of jewelry

loans.name: Elenoa

texts.en: Elenoa S., 38, is married and has six children.  She has three years of experience in the fishing business. She sells fish to the village people four days a week. She has had two previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about $145 USD).  SPBD loans are Elenoa’s only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She will use part of the loan to buy fishing equipment and and part of the loan to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: Purchase fishing equipment and pay for children's school fees.

loans.name: Makatala

texts.en:
Makatala T., 20, is single with no children. She has three years of experience in the transportation of the public to and from islands. She provides service to the public seven days per week.

She has one previous loan with SPBD. Makatala expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).

SPBD loans are Makatala’s only access to capital because she was not able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. Her loan will be used to upgrade the status of her business.

loans.use: Upgrade status of her business.

loans.name: Gerardo Eduardo

texts.es:
El señor Gerardo V. posee su propio negocio de venta de bisuterías y frutas en la ciudad de León de Nicaragua. Como todo padre responsable, busca la forma de cómo obtener el dinero para brindar el mantenimiento  a su familia compuesto por su esposa y su hijo.

La razón por la cual hoy en día él ha acudido a Ceprodel es para obtener un crédito para la compra de las frutas y bisuterías y así continuar en su negocio que tanto requiere desarrollo.
texts.en:
Mr. Gerardo V. has his own business selling costume jewelry and fruit in the city of León, Nicaragua. Like any responsible father, he looks for any way to get money to support his family, which includes his wife and son. The reason he has come today to Ceprodel is for a loan to buy fruit and costume jewelry to be able to further develop his business.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy costume jewelry and fruit

loans.name: Faasipa

texts.en: Faasipa F., 43, is married with 4 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the vegetables business. She sells to the village people and the general public 4 days per week. She has received 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Faasipa’s only access to capital, because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan from Kiva will be used to pay for vegetable seeds, sacks of fertilizer, wheelbarrow and a spade for the business, as well as her children's school fees, new school uniforms, and school supplies. Faasipa's husband is very good at fishing, and he goes fishing three times a week. Some of his catch is sold to earn extra income for the family, and some for family consumption.

loans.use: Purchase vegetable seeds, sacks of fertilizer, wheelbarrow and a spade. Some part will be for childrens school uniform and school fees.

loans.name: Elizabeth Del Carmen

texts.es:
En el mercado Central de la ciudad de León la señora Elizabeth M. se dedica a su actividad de venta de ropa y bisuterías teniendo su propio local donde a diario es visitada por sus clientes.

Es una dama muy esforzada y amante del trabajo por lo que está comprometida a llevar el sustento a sus tres hijos pequeños por ser madre soltera. La razón por la que acude a Ceprodel es para ser beneficiada con un crédito para la compra de la ropa y así salir adelante en su negocio.
texts.en:
In the central market of the city of Leon Mrs. Elizabeth Munillio makes a living selling clothing and costume jewelry in her own space which is frequented by her customers. She is a very hard working lady and loves her work as she is commited to support her three small children as a single mother. Her reason for coming to Ceprodel is to be granted a loan for the purchase of clothing and therefore be able to get ahead in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Anave

texts.en: Anave N., 50, is married with five children.  She has three years of experience in the Coffee shop business. She sells to the general public six days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Anave’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She will use her loan to purchase items for her business in order to become more successful.

loans.use: Purchase coffee, sugar, milk & box of plastic foam cups

loans.name: Blanca Nubia

texts.es:
La señora Blanca M. es una persona muy trabajadora cuya labor es la venta de alimentos en su localidad en la ciudad de León donde vende en las afueras de la calle alimentos y gaseosas. 

La razón por la cual espera en Ceprodel es para ser beneficiada con un crédito para la compra de la materia prima y por esta razón es que ella ha acudido a Ceprodel esperando que su crédito sea otorgado y así mejorar las condiciones de su negocio y seguir desarrollándose.
texts.en:
Mrs. Blanca M. is a very hard working person whose business is the sale of food in her area of the city of Leon where she sells groceries and sodas from a street stand. She is turning to Ceprodel wanting to be granted a loan for the purchase of raw materials and for this is wishing that her loan be approved and she can improve the condition of her business and continue to develop.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
La señora Marcela T. V. es originaria de la ciudad de León donde a diario se dedica a su actividad de venta de alimentos siendo este su único sustento con el cual mantiene su hogar.

Ella hoy en día atraviesa la necesidad de adquirir la material prima para la elaboración de los alimentos y debido a que el precio de tales productos se ha elevado, ella ha buscado el apoyo en Ceprodel para obtener un crédito y así adquirir la materia prima para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Mrs. Marcela T. V. is a resident of the city of Leon, where she dedicates her time daily to the sale of food, this being her only way to support her home. She is currently needing to obtain the raw materials for the making of the food. Since the the prices have risen, she is looking for the support of Ceprodel in obtaining a loan and thus being able to get the raw materials and being able to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

loans.name: Evaga

texts.en: Evaga, 39, is married with two children.  She has four years of experience in the Pork cake business. She sells to the school, village people and public three days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 100 Tala ($32 USD).  SPBD loans are Evaga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan for her business and to pay for her children's school fees. Her husband helps her with the business.

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, onion, yeast, and an oven and pay for school fees.

loans.name: Marina Isabel

texts.es:
La señora Marina R. es una dama digna de admirar por ser muy trabajadora y llevar el sustento a su casa de habitación por estar comprometida con el bienestar de este.

Hoy en día ella se dedica a su negocio de venta de comestibles como platanitos, galletas, frutas en bolsa, entre otros y para ello espera en Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito y de esta forma salir adelante en el negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Marina R. is a woman worthy of admiration because she is such a hard worker, and because she provides daily sustenance to the house where she lives. She is devoted to the well being of the people in her home.

She sells food like bananas, crackers, bagged fruit and other items. She hopes to get a loan. With help from Ceprodel, she will be able to get ahead in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Lote

texts.en: Lote, 34, is married with one child.  She has many years of experience in the pork bun business. She sells to the villagers and public five days per week. She has had one previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 320 Tala (~133 USD).  SPBD loans are Lote’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for her business

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann L. manages a small farm situated near the rough road in their small barrio in Norala, South Cotabato. She is 35 years old and has 4 children. Her husband is a farmer, Dante L., who helps her manage their farm. Together, they are tilling a 2-hectare land that she inherited from her parents.  Aside from rice, Mary Ann also raises cows. She loves cows, because they remind her of her grandparents who raise cows.

She is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers for her farm. The loan will help improve the fertility of the soil so she will have a good harvest.

CEVI provides Mary Ann the credit assistance that she needs to manage her farm well. She also receives training and insurance coverage services that CEVI gives to all their clients.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Opeta

texts.en: Opeta A., 39, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the taro and banana business. She sells to the villagers and the public 4 days per week. She has received 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Opeta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchasing equipment needed for improving her business

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina C. grows pigs in her backyard. She is 46 years old and has four children. Her husband, Richard C. is a farmer. Aside from pigs, the family owns a small rice farm which they use to feed and clothe their family.

She is also an active member of the health workers in their village. She is doing everything she thinks will benefit her and her family, to pay for their growing needs.

She is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase sacks of hog starter feed and piglets. The loan will help her increase the size of her piggery. In that way, she could have more pigs to sell and more income to earn.

Florentina is one of the thousand Filipino economically active poor helped by CEVI, to start and have their own business. She receives credit, training and insurance coverage from CEVI to help her small business grow.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of hog feed and piglets.

loans.name: Kalala Falefia

texts.en: Kalala Falefia, 54, is married with five children.  She has four years of experience in the Sewing business. She sells to the village people and the public five days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Kalala Falefia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy fabric and materials for her sewing business.

loans.name: Rufo

texts.en: Rufo, 38, is married with five children.  She has three years of experience in the Plantation business. She sells to the village people and the public two days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Rufo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase items needed to maintain her business.

loans.name: Ropeta

texts.en: Ropeta L., 38, is married with four children.  She has three years of experience in the ice-cake business. She sells to the village people and public six days per week. This is her first loan with Kiva's partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about $145).  SPBD loans are Ropeta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase plastic sheets, cups, sugar and cordial to make ice cake

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida F. is a pig grower. She is 51 years old, married and has two children. She started her business in 1979 . She loves hog raising because she enjoys what she is doing and earns a bigger income from raising pigs. She also owns a small rice farm.

Her husband, Nestor F. is tilling their 1.5 hectare farm to feed and clothe their family. Pigs and rice are their only means of livelihood. She dreamed that someday, one of her children will fulfill her dreams of becoming a teacher. She wanted all of them to graduate from college so that when they are old, they will have better jobs to support their families.

She is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy four sacks of feed for the pigs. She will also use some of the loans to increase the size of her pig fence. The loan will surely help Nida grow her piggery business.

CEVI helps her get a loan to run and sustain her business. Nida will receive credit, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: Purchase feed for her pigs and expand fence.

loans.name: Rocel

texts.en:
Rocel L. is one of the hard-working farmers who contributes to food productivity in her village. She has grown rice since she was just four years old. Her parents taught her about farming and how to have a good yield. Rocel cares for her family and especially for her seven children. Her husband is also a farmer. Both of them know the entire process of planting and growing rice, because they both came from the same village. 

Rocel is asking for a loan of $225 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more fertilizer to improve the soil of their farm. "Harvest depends on the type of soil you have," she said. "Fertilizers are one way to achieve a better yield," she added. 

CEVI is reaching out to more farmers to sustain their livelihood. They give all their clients training and insurance coverage in addition to credit.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
Rosana C. is a rice grower. She is 30 years old and has 2 loving children. She and her husband are renting land to grow rice. At first, the harvest was intended only for family consumption but there are times that they sell rice to their neighbors for additional family income. They have been tilling their farm for 20 years. Someday, they wish to buy their own farm and earn bigger income for the family.

She is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides. Specifically, she will buy 6 bags of Urea and 3 tanks of pesticides and chemicals. These are important to improve the soil profile and prevent insects from damaging the crops.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people sustain their livelihood. They also help people start and have their own business. They provide their clients not only credit but trainings and insurance coverage services as well.

loans.use: To purchase 6 bags of Urea fertilizers and 3 tanks of pesticides and chemicals.

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
Luciana B. manages a small rice farm in Norala, South Cotabato. Norala is a town with a population of 40,744 people and 8,263 households. Most of the people there are engaged in agriculture. When they are not growing rice, they raise livestock like cows, goats, buffaloes and lambs. They are also known for raising poultry animals like ducks, turkeys and chickens. Luciana is 57 years old and has big dreams for her 3 children.

She is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy 4 sacks of Urea. In addition to that, she plans to establish a new business. The loan will surely help increase her family yield and start the new business.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps farmers like Luciana sustain their business. They give opportunities especially to the rural poor to start businesses and make a livelihood for their families. CEVI gives credit assistance to all their clients. They also provide training and insurance coverage services to help them grow their business.

loans.use: Purchase 4 sacks of Urea and establish a new business

loans.name: Mili

texts.en: Mili L., 67, is married with eight children. She has four years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people/public three days per week. She has had three previous loans with Kiva's partner SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (about $166).  SPBD loans are Mili’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchases to maintain business needs

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta F. is 53 years old and is married with 7 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the Taro plantation business. Eseta sells to the school, village people and general public 5 days a week. She will use her loan to pay for her children’s school fees and also buy timber and cement for her house renovation. She has requested 1 loan previously from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 70 WST.  SPBD loans are Eseta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Pay for children’s school fees and purchase timber and cement for house renovation

loans.name: Lagi

texts.en:
Lagi M., 61, is widowed with eight children. She has two years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the school, villagers and the public five days per week. She has had one previous loan with Kiva's partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala. SPBD loans are Lagi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

Her loan will be used to buy sacks of flour, sugar, onions, yeast and a new oven to replace the old one.

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, onion, yeast and oven

loans.name: Zubaida M. Ishaq Group

texts.en:
Zubaida baji has been a citizen of a city named Borewala in Pakistan for the past 18 years. Her husband, M. I., is a driver by profession and drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). He has six years of experience in driving this vehicle. Zubaida baji is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her husband so that he gets the whole amount earned.

She is the group leader of six other women from her locality. Hamidan baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy wood to sell. Azra parveen baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats and sheep) to sell. Shaheen akhtar baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes-selling business. Parveen akthar baji wants a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food-selling business. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Tuuipo

texts.en:
Tuuipo L., 35, is married with seven children. She has four years of experience in the fishing business. She sells to the village people and to the public four days per week. She has had one previous loan with Kiva's partner SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 70 Tala.

SPBD loans are Tuuipo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase timber and cement for home improvement and the rest will be saved for the business.

loans.use: To buy timber and cement for home improvement

loans.name: Faasala

texts.en: Faasala L. is 32 years old and is divorced with 3 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the Taamu/Taro Plantation business. She sells to the public and village people in their village market in Safua twice a week. She has had 1 previous loan from SPBD. She will use her loan to buy cement, timber and iron roofing to renovate her house because it is getting damaged. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 WST.  SPBD loans are Faasala’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Buy cement, timber and iron roofing for home renovation

loans.name: Kaniza M. Ismail Group

texts.en:
Kaniza baji and her husband M. I. have lived in a city named Borewala in Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband has run a salon in the community for the past six years. Presently, he has two employees in his salon and he pays them bimonthly. Kaniza baji is applying for a loan to buy supplies (mirror, razors, creams and chairs) to give a new look to her husband’s salon.

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Gulshan baji and Parveen baji both want loans to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Rani baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy salon supplies

loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
Nelita D. manages a small mango farm in Norala, South Cotabato, a town of 40,744 people in 8,263 households. She is 51 years old, married and has 5 children. Before, she had a small eatery business, but due to downsizing of her customers, she decided to quit her food business and manage her farm instead. Her husband, Rodolfo D., is a farmer. Aside from mangoes, they grow other crops like cassava, taru, and "camote," which is the Philippine local name for sweet potato.

She is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 with CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her mango farm. These will help her improve her crop yield. This way, she could achieve a better harvest from her farm to support her family.

CEVI is helping her grow more mangoes. She receives credit assistance, training and insurance coverage services that CEVI gives to all their clients.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides for mango plantation

loans.name: Pandji

texts.en:
Y. Pandji is 58 years old and married with five children. He is currently living with only three of his children. All his life has been devoted to agricultural work, and on market days he brings his products to the market. For Pandji, the harvest is what he enjoys the most and he devotes a lot of time to sorting the potatoes that he will sell, because the price will depend on the size of the potato. Sorted, the potato is more profitable, although the potatoes he sells are not in great shape.

Agriculture is full of satisfaction for him and his family, even more when they sell for a good price at the market; that is the motivation to continue planting. This is the seventh loan that Pandji has had with IMON International. He makes his payments on time. And he is very grateful to those who support him, because they allow him to provide well-being to his family. With the money requested, he will buy seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants for his farm.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seed, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Ramzidin

texts.en:
Since he was young, Ramzidin has known how to work. His parents taught him how to get by as an agriculturalist, and he learned very well. Now that he is the father of a family, he still works as an agriculturalist. Thanks to his parents, Ramzidin now has the opportunity to move forward as a farmer, and he hopes to increase his agricultural products so that he can bring his loved ones a more promising life. Despite being a good agriculturalist and worker, he needs help to move forward and improve his production. This is why he is asking for a loan; so that he can buy more of the seeds and fertilizer he needs. These are very expensive, but without them, his production will not improve. You can help Ramzidin keep moving forward with his development plans.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Anecia

texts.en: Anecia, 49 years old, is married and lives in Tubod, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She has one child who is married. Her husband is a farmer. She inherited from her parents the coconut land her husband is tilling. She also raises chickens, ducks and pigs. She's been a Paglaum member for five years. She has had several loans already. Now, she is applying for PHP 14,900 to buy feed and piglets. She hopes to expand her business into a piggery someday.

loans.use: To buy feed and piglets

loans.name: Mon Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Mon Maiya lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in the Lalitpur district. Thecho is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming.
Mrs. Mon Maiya lives in a single-family home with her husband and three children. She has two sons and a daughter. Her older son completed his studies and her younger son is in grade four. Her daughter is in grade one.
Both Mrs. Mon Maiya and her husband work in their own clock shop. They opened their shop more than 15 years ago. They fulfill all their needs from that shop. Their older son also helps them in their shop. They sell different brands of watches and clocks. Now Mrs. Mon Maiya is requesting a loan of Rs 30000.00 to buy different brands of watches and clocks for the betterment of the shop.

loans.use: To buy watches and clocks for her store

loans.name: Maqsoodan Group

texts.en:
Maqsoodan baji is a widow. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her family for the last 10 years. Maqsoodan baji is a very hardworking lady. She did work as a seamstress for five years for her sons. Her elder son works as a deliveryman and delivers different items (furniture, construction supplies) from one place to another. The next son works in a factory on monthly wage. Maqsoodan baji is still working as a seamstress because she puts her profit in a committee savings plan. Her elder son is becoming of marriageable age and Maqsoodan baji plans to marry him off using the amount in her committee savings. Maqsoodan baji is applying for a loan to buy a donkey cart for her elder son because his old cart became rough and has broken in certain areas. 

Maqsoodan baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Sabra baji wants a loan to buy paint to sell. Qaisra baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothes. Fatima baji wants a loan to buy utensils to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a donkey cart

loans.name: Umeda

texts.en:
Umeda is 26 years old. She is not married yet. For almost seven years, Umeda has owned a beauty salon. Everyday she services many brides. In general, she offers bride-dresses, manicures, pedicures, make-up and hairstyles. Her salon is always full of clients because she does her job professionally. She wants to take a loan to extend her business. She wants to buy additional equipment and goods for her beauty shop. Umeda likes her job very much, because she likes to see the smiles of happy brides every day.

loans.use: To purchase goods for her beauty shop

loans.name: Tara Devi

texts.en: Tara Devi M. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family with her husband and one daughter. Her husband Mr. Shyam M. works in catering service. Her daughter is studying in grade 11. Mrs. M. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Thecho. She set up her grocery store six years ago to improve the economic condition of her family. Her husband and daughter also help her in the shop. She sells different types of grocery goods such as rice, maize, cold-drinks and various types of snacks. She requests a loan of Rs 30,000 to buy grocery goods. She will also use this loan to expand her shop.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods

loans.name: Makhfirat

texts.en:
M. Makhfirat is a hard-working woman. She is married with three children, two of whom are married and have their own family. For the past 10 years, Makhfirat has dedicated herself to selling office supplies. She started her business after her husband's contract with the construction company he was employed with terminated. She then decided to generate her own income to try to fill the gap. She enjoys her business and has developed a stable enterprise. Makhfirat has requested a loan of $ 800 USD to purchase new supply of items to sell. She commits to paying her loan back within 12 months. This loan is important for her family's well-being as it will help Makhfirat’s business grow. She truly appreciates your generosity. 

Tajikistan
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history and diverse culture, which is a mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet influence, and Central Asian traditions. It served as a key post along the Silk Road and marked the end of Alexander the Great's extensive rule. It was the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina. And it is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. 

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.
