Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing office supplies for selling

loans.name: Wema Group

texts.en: Grace K. has been a rice seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya since past four years. She belongs to Wema group loan (Group code 2008). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $300. She works for 10 hours everyday. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more rice for her business. She hopes the loan will help her increase her profits and grow her business. Grace K. is 35 years old, married, and has three children, aged 11, 6 and 1. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Grace D., who also owns a small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more rice for her business.

loans.name: Nasreen M.iqbal Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji has been a citizen of a city named Borewala, Pakistan for the past 15 years. She belongs to a poor family. For this reason she couldn’t get an education. She is the mother of three daughters. All of her daughters are getting an education and this all happens because of Nasreen baji, because she wants to give her daughters a good future and it wouldn’t be possible without an education.

Nasreen baji is a determined lady; she embroiders clothes to pay off the school fees of her daughters and the other school expenses (uniforms, books). Nasreen baji’s husband’s name is M. and he operates a fruit-selling business. He has 6 years of experience in this business. Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her husband’s fruit-selling business. Nasreen baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Mussarat shamim baji wants a loan to buy cigarettes to sell. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy fruits for her fruit-selling business. Hurmat baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits for her husband's business

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en: Mrs. Felomina B. is 47 years old, married and lives in the neighborhood of Mobod in Oroquieta City. She has 3 children and her husband is a fisherman. In order to help her husband support the family, she opened a “sari-sari” store in front of their house. The daily needs of her family is helped from the income of the store. Last February 2009, she joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative to use its loan facilities and benefits program that are given to its members such as; savings, patronage refund, dividend, and insurances. Today, she is applying for a loan of PHP 3,000 to buy additional goods to sell. She plans to expand her business and if given a chance, expand her business into a mini – grocery store.

loans.use: to buy additional goods for a sar-sari store

loans.name: Subadhara

texts.en:
Subadhara T. lives in a single family home in Sainbu-Bhaishipati. Sainbu-Bhaishipati is located in the Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. She lives with her husband and three daughters. Her husband Mr. Rajendra works in a noodle factory. Her three daughters are studying in grades 12, 11 and 6 respectively.

Mrs. T. is a farmer and she prefers to grow seasonal vegetables on her land. She especially likes to grows green vegetables. She sells her vegetables daily, at a local market in the morning and evening.

She is now requesting  a loan for Rs 20000.00 to buy seeds and fertilizers for her farm. She needs to spend her income on her daughter's education.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosario R. is married, and a new member of Paglaum. Her husband is a carpenter. She has 3 children and her family lives in Purok, Sapang Dalaga.

She is requesting a loan as additional capital for her sari-sari store. The income of her husband is not enough for their daily needs and she is looking to increase their source of income. She decided  then to own and operate a sari-sari store and now plans is to expand her store into a convenience Store. She wishes to see her children succeed in their chosen fields of education.

loans.use: To purchase additional sari-sari store supplies

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Thirty-six year old Mrs. Ruth S. is married, with five children. Her husband is a motorcycle-for-hire driver with a minimal income for his family. Out of five children, three are studying.

Ruth engages in selling snacks made of rice and coconut milk commonly known as "puto".  The purpose of her loan obtained from Paglaum Coop is for additional capital for her existing livelihood in order to help her husband in raising their children and to lift their life from poverty.

loans.use: To purchase of rice, sugar, and coconut

loans.name: Sarvar

texts.en:
A. Sarvar is 35 years old, and married to Gafurov Askarali who is an entrepreneur. They live in their own house with the basic necessities. They have three children.

Sarvar has been the owner of a small general store for more than three years. She sells foodstuff for everyday use such as rice, flour, macaroni, soft drinks, sweets. etc. Sarvar runs her business from her home and her children help her. The motivation for requesting a loan is to be able to purchase more merchandise to stock the business. A larger selection of goods will attract more clients and generate a good monthly income to help her family. Support this woman who has much strength and courage to keep working.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Kamala

texts.en:
Mrs. Kamala N., a resident of Sainbu-Bhaishipati, lives in a single family home with her husband and two children. Sainbu-Bhaishipati is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Her husband, Mr. Krishna N., works in a private office. She has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade 5 and daughter is in grade 4.

Mrs. N. is engaged in goat farming. Now she has four goats on her farm. She sells the goats in the local market. This business helps her to contribute something to upgrade the living standards of her family. Now she is requesting a the third loan of Rs 20000.00 to buy a few more goats and foods grains for the goats.

loans.use: To buys goats

loans.name: Fakhriddin

texts.en:
K. Fakhriddin is 51 years old. He is married with four children. Since he was young, he has been in the business of raising and selling cattle, which is why he has a lot of experience. It is necessary to point out that he has been able to succeed thanks to the support provided by IMON International. This support has been in the form of a loan which he has used to purchase and raise young bulls.

Today, Fakhriddin has once again come to IMON International for a loan which will allow him to purchase young bulls to raise and sell. It is his biggest dream to improve the conditions of his business in order to then improve the conditions of his family.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase young cattle

loans.name: Wema Group

texts.en:
Veronica has been a clothes (Vitenge) seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for four years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $350. Each day she works at her business for 10 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more clothes to sell. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Veronica is married, and has five children: ages 25, 22, 18, 16 and 3. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Lucy, who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: Buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Durga

texts.en:
Durga T. lives in Sainbu-Bhaishipati, Lalitpur, in a joint family with her father in law, husband and two children. Her husband Brijeshpati T. works in a restaurant. She has one son and one daughter. Her daughter is studying in grade three and son is in first grade.

Durga wants to start a goat farm because she knows that she can earn more profit. She also has experience in this job.

She is requesting Rs15,000 to start a goat farming business. She will use this loan to buys goats and food grains for the goats.

loans.use: Buy goats and feed.

loans.name: Shanti

texts.en:
Shanti T. lives in Sanepa, Lalitpur. It is one of the busy cities of Lalitpur and most people in this region are engaged in small business.

Shanti lives in a single family home with her husband and two children. She had one son and one daughter. Both are studying in primary school.

Shanti and her husband Bhim Bahadur T. opened their grocery shop two years ago. They sell different types of grocery items like rice, maize, paddy, noodles and so on.

Now Shanti is requesting for Rs.15,000 loan to buy different types of grocery items for her business. She wants to use her increased income to provide a better education for her children.

loans.use: Buy grocery goods.

loans.name: Nodira

texts.en:
Nodira is 44 years old. She and her husband raised four children. For more than five years Nodira has run her own business.

She has a small saloon where she sells and rents traditional wedding dresses and the national wedding dress. Traditionally, families in Tajikistan are large, consequently there are lots of marriages and Nodira has a lot of clients. The stability of her business allows her to make a considerable contribution to the family’s income.

Today Nodira requests $ 800 to purchase more new wedding dresses. Nodira would like to assure all lenders that she will repay the loan.

------------------------------------------------------------------

loans.use: Purchase new wedding dresses.

loans.name: Wema Group

texts.en:
Zarina has been a clothes seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for five years. She belongs to Wema group (Group code: 2008). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $350. She works at her business for 10 hours daily.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more clothes "vitenge" for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Zarina is 45 years old, married, and has eight children: ages 30, 27, 25, 21, 18, 17, 15 and 7. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Valentina who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: Buy more clothes (vitenge) for her business.

loans.name: Kattaboy

texts.en:
Kattaboy is a hardworking young gentleman who works in the cattle raising business.

He is married and provides for his little son. He works hard to provide everything his family needs. Presently, Kattaboy is making sacrifices and working hard to make his business grow.

He is requesting a loan that will allow him to purchase baby cows with the purpose of feeding them and raising them. Kattaboy's goal is to get the most return from the sale of milk products. This will be his first loan with IMON and Kiva, and his evaluation shows he is qualified to receive the loan.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase calves.

loans.name: Sanu

texts.en:
Sanu L. lives with her husband, Chakra Bahadur L. and their three children. Her husband is a taxi driver in the Kathmandu valley. Her two daughters are studying in grades nine and three respectively and her son is in primary school.

Sanu opened her small business three years ago to strengthen the economic condition of her family. She sells different food items in her shop. In particular, she makes Nepali food such as DalBhat (rice). She also sells tea and coffee.

The demand for food is increasing in her area, so Sanu is requesting her first loan of Rs15,000 to buy necessary ingredients for her shop.

loans.use: Buy food materials.

loans.name: Nani Maiya

texts.en:
Nani Maiya is a farmer in Sanepa. She mostly grows green vegetables on her land. She depends on seasonal farming due to the lack of modern tools and technology.

She sells her vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening, daily. Now she is requesting a Rs15,000 loan to buy fertilizer and seeds for her farming work.

Nani lives with her husband, two sons, and one daughter. Her husband, Asha Kazi D. is a driver. Her daughter is studying at the BBS level. Her older son is studying in grade 10 and younger son is in grade nine.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Sumina

texts.en:
Sumina lives in Tangal, Lalitpur. She is at one of the very busy bazaars of Lalitpur, and most of the people in this region are engaged in making metal kitchen utensils.

Sumina lives in a single family with her husband and two children. She has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade three and daughter is only a year old.

Her husband, Krishna S. makes different types of religious brass statues. He started this work more than 10 years ago. Now Sumina has also started doing this work. They make statues according to orders from dealers.

Now Sumina is requesting Rs25,000 to buy raw materials such as wax, bronze, etc. for statue making work.

loans.use: Buy raw materials for her work.

loans.name: Balqys Group

texts.en:
Palwasha is the group leader of Balqys group. Each of the four members of this group would like to receive a loan for her own business.

Balqys and Habiba would like a loan for their husbands' fruit cart businesses, so they can buy necessary materials.
Palwasha would like a loan to enlarge her leather-sewing business.
Mastora would like a loan for her tailoring business, to increase her inventory.

With this loan they can improve their businesses and support their families, thus making a better future for themselves and their families.

loans.use: Expand a leather-sewing business

loans.name: Devmaiya

texts.en:
Devmaiya M. is a resident of Chetrapati, located in Kathmandu district. Most people in this area are engaged in small businesses.

She has three members, including herself in her family. Devmaiya has one daughter who attained grade seven. Both Devmaiya and her husband, Ratna M. opened their grocery shop five years ago, in their own house. They sell different types of grocery items like rice, maize, paddy, noodles and so on.

Now Mrs. M. is requesting Rs.10,000 loan to buy different types of grocery items for her business. She would like to use her increased income to provide a better education to her daughter.

loans.use: Buy grocery items.

loans.name: Amani Group

texts.en:
Happy has owned a small shop in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for four years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more commodities in order to increase her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Happy is 21 years old and single. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mastura, who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more commodities in order to increase her current stock

loans.name: Babita

texts.en:
Mrs. Babita B. lives in Chetrapati. Chetrapati is located in the Kathmandu district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses.

Mrs. B. lives in a single family with her husband and two daughters. Her older daughter is studying in grade 8 and her younger daughter is in grade 1.

Both Mrs. B. and her husband, Mr. Bisho Kiran B., are engaged in the same grocery shop. They opened their grocery shop three years ago. They sell different types of grocery items such as rice, maize, pulse (a vegetable), biscuits and noodles in their shop. Their older daughter also helps them in their work. Now Mrs. B. is requesting a Rs 10000.00 loan to buy grocery items to meet demand.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Amna M. Irshad Group

texts.en:
Amna baji is married to M. I. and has lived in Borewala, Pakistan for five years. Her husband makes a living selling wheat, and has been in this line of work since 2002. Amna has five children, three sons and two daughters. Her older two sons help their father with his wheat-selling business. The other children are all in school. Amna baji is applying for a loan to buy wheat for her husband to sell. 

Amna baji leads a group made up of three other women. Nasira abbas baji wants a loan to buy calling cards for her public calling office, where people come to make calls. Faizan baji wants a loan to buy leather to sell. Salamat baji wants a loan to buy food items to sell in her grocery store.

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wheat and other items to sell

loans.name: Sanju

texts.en: Mrs. Sanju R. lives in Chetrapati, Kathmandu with her husband and one son, who is in primary school. Both Mrs. R. and her husband make a living running a clothing store, which opened five years ago and sells many different types of garments. The store is their family's sole source of income. Mrs. R. is applying for a loan to expand her business by buying different types of garments to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy more clothing to sell from her shop

loans.name: Amani Group

texts.en:
Furaha makes a living selling cooking oil in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya. She earns an average monthly profit of $300, and works at her business for 12 hours a day.

She is applying for her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more cooking oil to sell to her customers. She is hopping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to expand her business.  

Furaha is 23 years old, married, and has a seven-month-old child.  She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Salome, who also has a small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Jamuna

texts.en:
Mrs. Jamuna is a shopkeeper in the town of Chetrapati, Kathmandu. She opened her grocery store six years ago as a way to strengthen the economic condition of her family. She sells different types of items, including rice, maize and snacks. Competition is tougher than it used to be because there are now lots of grocery stores near hers. To stay in business, she needs to sells goods cheaply, and that means investing money in her store. That is why Mrs. Jamuna is requesting a loan to make her store better
.
Mrs. Jamuna is married and has three children, all of whom are still in school

loans.use: to buy goods to sell in her grocery store

loans.name: Shova

texts.en:
Shova B. makes a living running a garment shop that she opened five years ago. In her shop, she sells many different types of clothes for both men and women. She opened the shop to raise the living standard of her family, and is applying for this loan to buy new and different types of clothes to improve her shop.

Mrs. B. is married and lives with her husband and their two sons. Her husband, Mr. Ratna Chandra, works in an office. Her older son in in the 12th grade and her younger son is in the 8th grade.

loans.use: to buy different types of clothing to sell to her customers

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is a resident of Magsaysay, Sibutad, Zamboanga del Norte. She’s 35, married and has two kids who are both in elementary school. Her husband is a miner. She operates a sari-sari (variety) store in her barangay (village), which she established using her family's savings.

Mary Jane became a member of the Paglaum Cooperative last September and took out a loan worth Php 5,000.00 as additional capital for her sari-sari store. She plans to use the money to purchase grocery items. Mary Jane's hopes and dreams are to expand the business, for it to become a mini grocery store in the future and for both of her children to finish college.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items

loans.name: Amani Group

texts.en:
Anaganilye has been a seller of local alcohol in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for 4 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 250. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more local alcohol for re-sale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Anaganilye is 33 years old, married, and has two children: ages 14 and 12. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Upendo, who has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more local alcohol for re-sale

loans.name: Zinduka Group

texts.en:
Ester has been an onion, fish and tomato seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for 17 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 300. Each day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more onions, fish and tomatoes for re-sale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Ester is 46 years old, married, and has four children: ages 25, 22, 18 and 14. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Asia, who has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more onions, fish and tomatoes for re-sale

loans.name: Sayma Group

texts.en:
Najeba is the group leader of the Sayma group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their own business.

Najeba and Sayma want to take a loan for their carpentry business. They will use the loan to buy necessary materials for their business. Najeba wants to take a loan for her husband’s business. They all want to see progress in their businesses and to earn more money to support their families and solve their problems.

They believe that these loans can be very useful because they provide a chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy carpentry materials

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao L. is a forty-year-old widowed mother caring for five children. All of them are students and help her with her business when they are not studying. She currently makes a daily income to support her family by selling chickens and some vegetables in the local market, and generates an average income of $3 a day. She is a self-sacrificing woman who works hard every day and never wastes time. Sao L. has been hiring a neighbor's motorcycle for her business transportation for a long time. She has hoped to have her own motorcycle, and to make that possible she has decided to apply for a loan of $700. Her family lives in Siem Reap Province, in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Rolybeth

texts.en:
Rolybeth L. is 38 years old and married to a tricycle (local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver, with three children. She was engaged in farming as one of their main ways to make a living. She became a member of PDP-LP in March 2007.

Rolybeth accessed the credit services offered by the program and she’s on her 3rd loan amounting to Php 6,000, used for purchase of fertilizers. Her project is farming and she is expecting to have a good harvest. Her dream is that all her kids can finish a course of study and can live independently in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer

loans.name: Tushikamane Group

texts.en:
Mwanaid has been an onion seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for 4 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 60. Every day she works at her business for 10 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more onions for re-sale in order to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Mwanaid is 45 years old, married, and has seven children: ages 23, 20, 18, 18, 15, 10 and 6. She also cares for two additional dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Telesia, who has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more onions for re-sale

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea R., 51, has been selling Khmer noodles out of her home for more than nine years. She sells them every morning for the villagers' breakfast. She is a widow and the mother of six children, five of whom are still living in the family home. To help pay for the family's daily expenses, one of Chea's daughters sells desserts in a location near Entertainment place, in Siem Reap province. R. has requested a loan of $400 as capital in order to buy more ingredients necessary for her business activities.

loans.use: To buy necessary ingredients

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita, 63 years old and married, lives in Talairon, Oroquieta City. She has 3 children. Her husband is a pensioner. Nenita is interested in rice retailing, that’s why she has ventured into this kind of business. For her, it is very saleable because Filipinos eat rice thrice a day.

The working capital will not be a hindrance for her because she has been a member of Paglaum since May 2002. Recently she applied for PHP 25,000 to buy more sacks of rice for retailing. She hopes that her business will become successful in order to gain more profit and more blessings for her family as well.

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice for sale

loans.name: Zinduka Group

texts.en:
Judith has been a clothes seller for 5 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. She works at her business for 10 hours daily.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for resale in order to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Judith is 46 years old, married, and has seven children: ages 26, 25, 24, 22, 18, 16 and 9. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Helieth, who also has her own small business nearby.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Sharefy Group

texts.en:
Zabayr Ralah is the group leader of Sharefy group. There are five members in this group. All of them would like to borrow money for their businesses.

Zabayr Ralah and Khan A. are requesting a loan to buy necessary materials for their general store. Rayza Gull and Bibi Sara need a loan for their tailoring business to buy new equipment. Bibi Latefa requires a loan to improve her quilt business. They have requested a loan of 50000 Afghani. 

The group members will put this loan to full use expanding and improving their businesses. They appreciate the Kiva partnership in Afghanistan which supports poor people.

loans.use: Materials for a general store

loans.name: Cipriana

texts.en:
Cipriana, 49 years old, is married and lives in San Vicente Bajo. She has 2 children; one of them is studying in college. Her husband is a government employee. Together with her parents, she displays “guinamos” (i.e., salted fish) in the public market. She sells the salted fish during market days in Aloran and Oroquieta City every Sunday and Saturday. She sells it in volume.

On other days, a “sari-sari” (variety) store in their house is her business. Being a MIGS member, she has already accessed 15 loans. Now, for her 16th, she is applying for PHP 36,000 to buy cans of salted fish and additional goods for her sari-sari store. She plans to renovate their house someday.

loans.use: to buy cans of salted fish and goods for "sari-sari" store

loans.name: Rukany

texts.en:
Rukany is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and is requesting a loan to buy a motor-bike for the transportation of vegetables to the market. Rukany is 42 years old and is widowed. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy a motor-bike for the transportation of vegetables to market

loans.name: Violor

texts.en:
Violor is currently in the business of selling bread and is requesting a loan to buy ingredients for baking bread. Violor is 32 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy ingredients for baking bread

loans.name: Tushikamane Group

texts.en:
Fadhili has been a cosmetics seller in the Nzovwe neighborhood of Mbeya for 5 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 125. Each day she works at her business for 10 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more cosmetics items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Fadhili is 30 years old, married, and has three children: ages 13, 8 and 6. She also cares for one additional dependent. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Tabia, who has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics items for her business

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
Alejandra, is from Oroquita City. She is famous for her pillow cases and curtains. She is a dressmaker. Her husband is an expert in tailoring pants and uniforms. They both agreed to continue the business as a couple. She was trained by her husband to cut and sew simple pillow cases at first. Later on, she learned different styles of cutting and tailoring.

Their primary customers are their neighbors and relatives. In order to cater for all of them, they hired an employee and paid him based on the number of items he made. Recently, she applied for PHP 14,900 to buy meters of cloth for dresses and pillow cases. In the future, she hopes that they will have a tailor shop in the heart of the city.

loans.use: to buy meters of cloth for pillow cases, curtains, and dresses

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is currently in the business of selling bread and is requesting a loan to buy more bread for sale. Rose is 40 years old and widowed. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land she rents.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more bread for re-sale

loans.name: Say

texts.en: Say C. is 26 years old and a resident of Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia. She is married to Mr. Sony, who is a taxi driver, and they have one lovely young child. Say owns farmland that she inherited from her grandparents. She grows vegetables and some fruit trees. She sells her produce to market retailers every five months, when her crops mature. Cashew season is approaching, so she is applying for a $600 loan to purchase cashews that she will store in the family home for a while and then later resell for income..

loans.use: To purchase cashew

loans.name: Nasreen M. Tariq Nadeem Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the group leader. She is a very active lady. She performs all the responsibilities of a group leader and she is a good housewife also. She has three kids: two girls and one boy. She takes care of them and gets up early, then prepares breakfast for her family. All of her family is very happy with her.

Nasreen baji’s husband's name is M. Tariq N., a vegetable seller with experience over the past 6 years. He buys vegetables at cheap rates from the vegetable market and sells to the community by announcing his products on a cart in a loud voice. Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to expand her husband’s vegetable-selling business.

She is the group leader for three other women from her locality. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy leather to sell. Zainab baji wants a loan to buy vegetables to sell. Samina Kosar baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables to re-sell

loans.name: Makunguru Group

texts.en:
Rehema has been a cloth (vitenge--traditional cloth) seller in the Mwanjelwa neighborhood of Mbeya for 4 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 175. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more cloth (vitenge) for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Rehema is 39 years old, married, and has a 12-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Simwata, who has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more cloth (vitenge) for her business

loans.name: Sugran Nazir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Sugran baji is the wife of N. A. who lives in a city named Borewala, Pakistan for the past 9 years. Sugran baji operates a clothes-sewing business. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband. Sugran baji’s husband belongs to a sanitary supplies-selling business with experience over the past 6 years. Sugran baji is applying for a loan to buy supplies (pipes & taps) to sell.

She is the group leader for five other women from her locality. Shamshad baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Salma baji want a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Najma Kosar baji wants a loan to buy decorative items to sell. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her medical store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy sanitary supplies for re-sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary M. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and beans and is requesting a loan to build a storeroom for flour and beans that she can also sell out of. Mary is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has no children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: build a storeroom for flour and beans and sell from that storeroom

loans.name: Tagoynazar

texts.ru: Клиент Садулоев Тагойназар в возросте 34-ёх лет имеет двух детей  проживающий в районе Абдурахмони Джоми. Высшего образования не имеет, клиент занимается животноводством уже более 4 ёх лет. На полученные деньги клиент, хочет купить пару малодых телят.От продажи скота клиент имеет доход, этот доход помогает содержать семью.
texts.en:
Tagoynazar S. is 34 years old and has two children. He lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He does not have a high education and does animal husbandry for more than four years already. He will use the loan money to buy a couple of young calves. He makes a profit from selling cattle and this income helps him support his family.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Zenap

texts.en:
Zenap A., 27 years old and married to a business man, has three children, all in school. Currently selling food at a hotel, A. is requesting a loan to buy more sacks of rice, beans, etc. for the business. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children’s school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of rice, beans, etc. for her food business at the hotel.

loans.name: Makunguru B Group

texts.en:
Getruda has been a clothes and snacks seller in the Mwanjelwa neighborhood of Mbeya for 6 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day she works at her business for 9 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and snacks item for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Getruda is 30 years old, married, and has 3 children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Rehema, who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: Buy more clothes and snacks to sell

loans.name: Makunguru B Group

texts.en:
Tabia has been selling maize and beans in the Mwanjelwa neighborhood of Mbeya for 5 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. Every day she works at her business for 10 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more maize and beans for resale in order to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Tabia is 48 years old, married, and has 6 children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Lucy, who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: Buy more maize and beans for resale

loans.name: Araba

texts.en:
Araba B. is currently selling goods at her shop, and is requesting a loan to build another shop for selling goods. Araba is 25 years old and her husband is a business man. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profit she can earn from selling more goods in an additional shop, she hopes to be able to buy land and build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Build another shop for selling goods

loans.name: Nurullo

texts.ru: Клиент Улаев Нурулло 52- ух  летний мужчина, проживающий в районе Абдурахмони Джоми. Женат имеет 7 рых детей имеет средне техническое образования, по специальности механизатор.По специальности работал 33 года, после сокращения должности начил заниматься животноводством.На полученные деньги клиент хочет купить пару молодых телят. Клиент откармливает и продаёт скот, от продажи скота клиент расширит своё хозяйства.
texts.en:
Our client, Nurullo U., is a 52-year-old man who lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He is married and has seven children. He completed a secondary vocational school and is a machine operator by profession. He worked in this specialty for 33 years, but after retirement went into raising livestock. U. wants to purchase a pair of young calves with this loan. He raises and sells cattle, and from the sale of those cattle he expands his farm.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Makunguru B Group

texts.en:
Agnes, a charcoal seller in the Mwanjelwa neighborhood of Mbeya for the past five years, works 11 hours daily and currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal for resale to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Anges is 40 years old, married, and has four children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Helena, who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for resale to improve her business.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is currently in the business of selling shoes and clothes and is requesting a loan to buy a tailoring machine for sewing many clothes. Teresa is 30 years old and is widowed. She has no children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land and build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy a tailoring machine for sewing many clothes for sale

loans.name: Naimat Atta Ullah Group

texts.en:
Naimat baji is a citizen of a mid-size city named Vehari, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Naimat baji is a very hardworking lady; she performs her duties as a mother and as a wife very effectively. She is not an educated lady but she knows the value of education. She keeps herself involved in a clothes-sewing business because she wants to give her children a better education.

Naimat baji’s husband's name is A. U. and he has an animal-selling business. He has been doing this work for the past 6 years. He sells animals to the butcher shops and animal markets also. Naimat baji is applying for a loan to buy goats for her husband’s animal-selling business.

Naimat baji is the group leader for three other women from her locality. Yasmeen baji wants a loan to buy mason's tools. Rubina Shaheen baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes to sell. Bilquis baji wants a loan to buy cigarettes to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy goats to re-sell

loans.name: Xayrullo

texts.ru: Клиент Улаев Нурулло 38- ми  летний мужчина, проживающий в районе Абдурахмони Джоми. Женат имеет 7 рых детей имеет средне техническое образования, по специальности учитель физкультуры.Сам клиент занимается животноводством уже несколько лет.На полученные деньги клиент хочет купить пару молодых телят. Клиент откармливает и продаёт скот,на полученную прибыль клиент содержит семью.
texts.en:
Our client, Xayrullo U., is a 38-year-old man who lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He is marrried with seven children. He completed a secondary vocational school and by profession is a physical education teacher. Xayrullo has raised livestock for several years, and with this loan he wishes to purchase a pair of young calves. Xayrullo raises and sells cattle, supporting his family on the profits he makes.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Najma Parveen  Noor Muhammad Group

texts.en:
Najma Parveen baji is a citizen of a mid-size city named Vehari, Pakistan for the past 11 years. Najma baji is married to a man whose name is N. M. and he is a butcher by trade. He sells particularly chicken meat. He runs a shop in the main market of Vehari. People come to him to buy chicken meat because his scales are very fair. Najma baji is applying for a loan to buy more chickens to sell as chicken meat.

Najma baji is the group leader for three other women from her locality. Ishrat baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Naseem Kosar baji wants a loan to buy furniture (chairs and tables) for her tutoring center. Kosar baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, cooking oil, and spices) for her food-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy chickens for chicken meat business

loans.name: Benk A Group

texts.en:
Enick has been a food seller in the Mwanjelwa neighborhood of Mbeya for 6 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 90. Daily she works at her business for 10 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Enick is 45 years old, married, and has seven children. She also cares for two additional dependents. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Edah and Lucia. Each woman has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Dedeba

texts.en:
Debada is currently in the business of selling charcoal and firewood at home and is requesting a loan to build a shop. Dedaba is 20 years old and is divorced. She has 3 children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children later on.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: build a shop

loans.name: Nargis Ghulam Mustafa Group

texts.en:
Nargis baji is the wife of G. M., who has lived in a mid-size city named Vehari, Pakistan, for the last 8 years. She is the mother of three sons. All are getting an education at a local school. Nargis baji operates a business sewing clothes. She learned this art from her husband, who operates a tailoring center in the community. He has been in this profession for the last 4 years. People come to him to stitch their clothes. He charges $2 for normal stitching, and $3 for designer clothes. Nargis baji is applying for a loan to buy an electric sewing machine for her husband’s tailoring center.

Nargis baji is the group leader of another three women from her area. Anwari baji requests a loan to buy mason's tools. Rukhsana baji requests a loan to buy a welding machine. Naseem akhtar baji requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Buy an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Ilolo Group

texts.en:
Faines has sold maize and snacks in the Mwanjelwa neighborhood of Mbeya for 6 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. Each day she works at her business for 10 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more maize and snacks to sell in her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Faines is 45 years old, married, and has 7 children, between the ages of 25 and 17. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Niku and Veronica Telesia. Each woman also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: Buy more maize and snacks to sell

loans.name: Parveen Mai M. Mushtaq Group

texts.en:
My name is Parveen Mai and I’ve lived in a city named Vehari, Pakistan, for the last 10 years. My husband's name is M. Mushtaq, and he sells different types of utensils, such as steel and glass. He buys the utensils from different cities (Lahore and Muzafarabad) and sells them in his native city. He has a good number of customers. He has been in this profession for the last 6 years.

I am a mother of three kids: two sons and one daughter. All of my kids are enrolled in a local school near my house. I operate a business sewing clothes. I do this work to pay the school fees for my kids, because they want to get a good education and make be independent. My family is very happy with my co-operative and sincere behavior. I am requesting for a loan to expand my husband’s business selling utensils.

I am the group leader of 4 other women from my area. Zainab baji requests a loan to buy animals (goats and sheep) to sell. Hamidan baji requests a loan to buy thread to sell. Ghazala and Leeb baji and Khursheed baji each request a loan to change the body of their auto-rickshaws (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Buy utensils to sell

loans.name: Meyhi El Dien

texts.en:
Meyhi El Dien is a 31-year-old man who lives in the southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Meyhi El Dien has been working as a car repairman for eleven years. He also takes care of the car interiors. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is the first time that Meyhi El Dien has requested a loan.

Meyhi El Dien is speciA. in his work because he does it well and he does a professionA. job. His clients can be anybody, but mainly his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had difficulty finding the proper place to open his garage. Meyhi El Dien decided on doing his business because he has experience in this field. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: to purchase tools for his work

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is a 37-year-old man who lives in the southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their child. Hasan has owned a fish shop for twenty-five years. He sells all kinds of fish, depending on the season. Hasan requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a new refrigerator and do some maintenance work in his shop. This is the first time that Hasan has requested a loan.

Hasan is special in his work because he fishes for different types of fish; his shop is clean as well. His clients are his friends, neighbors and people from his region. When Hasan first started his business, he didn’t have any difficulty. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent job. In the future, Hasan plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: purchase a new refrigerator and do some maintenance work in his shop

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 38 years old and married with 4 children. She sells foodstuffs and drinks. Since the demand of her customers is high, she wants to satisfy them. Josephine needs the loan amount of N 70,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell. She lives in  Lagos State, Nigeria. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Ade

texts.en: Ade is 37 years old; she sells foodstuffs, provisions, and drinks. She is married with 4 children. She lives in  Lagos State, Nigeria. She wants to satisfy the demand of her customers by requesting the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs, provisions, and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs, provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of seasonal goods

loans.name: Bashiran Rana Khalid Group

texts.en:
Bashiran baji is the wife of R. K. and they have lived in a mid-size city named Vehari, Pakistan for the past 15 years. She is the mother of four kids: two sons and two daughters. Her sons are enrolled in a school, getting an education. Her daughters don't study and help her in her decorative embroidery business. Her husband operates a clothes-selling business. He has been in this profession for the past 10 years. He buys clothes from a famous city (Multan) and sells them in his native city. Sometimes Bashiran baji helps him also by selling his clothes in the community. She is applying for a loan to buy clothes to expand her husband’s clothes-selling business.

Bashiran baji is the group leader for four other women from her locality. Suraiya Naheed baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell. Another Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy goats and sheep for her animal-selling business. Zuhra baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Najma Syed Guftar Shah Group

texts.en:
Najma baji has been a citizen of a mid-sized city named Vehari, Pakistan for the past 18 years. Najma baji’s husband, S. G. S., deals with animals. He has been selling animals for the past 11 years. Najma baji, a housewife, has two sons who are getting education. She also operates a sewing business, which allows her to pay the expenses of her sons’ education. She is applying for a loan to buy animals (goats & sheep) for her husband’s animal selling business. 

This is a group loan, and Najma baji is the leader. Two other women from her city are in the group. Zainab baji wants a loan to buy mason tools. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her animal selling business.

The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals to sell

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: Mamadou N. est un tailleur qui habite au quartier Som de Thiès.  Il sollicite ce prêt pour l’acquisition d’une nouvelle machine à coudre afin de faire face aux nouveaux modèles des femmes.  Tailleur de profession ce prêt lui permet de renforcer son activité pour pouvoir se marier dans le futur et bien entretenir sa famille.
texts.en:
Mamadou N. is a tailor in the Som neighborhood in Thiès. He's seeking this loan to buy a new sewing machine, in order to be able to make new designs for women. A trained tailor, this loan will enable him to bolster his business, in order to get married in the future and take care of his family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Abdoulaye Dioume

texts.fr: Abdoulaye Dioume M. est un forgeron depuis dix ans qui fabrique des marmites pour les vendre.  Il habite au quartier cité Keur Dago de Thiès, et il est marie.  Ce prêt lui permet d’avoir un fond de roulement pour pouvoir faire face à la forte demande de ses clients.  Monsieur M. a déjà reçu deux crédits auprès de l’IMCEC et il les a bien remboursée.  Les revenus de son entreprise lui permettent d’entretenir sa famille.
texts.en:
Abdoulaye Dioume M. has been a blacksmith for ten years, making and selling saucepots. He lives in the Keur Dago neighborhood in Thiès, and he is married. This loan will enable him to have a working capital, in order to meet strong customer demand. Mr. M. already benefited from two loans from Kiva's partner IMCEC, which were repaid without problems. The profits of his business enables him to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To have a working capital for his business

loans.name: Falilat

texts.en: Falilat is 26 years old and married with 2 children. She sells building materials. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more building materials to sell.  She thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en: Mohamed N. is 22 years old and lives with his wife and his 3 children in Gaza, Palestine. Mohamed operates an Internet café that also offers photocopying services. He needs a loan of $1200 so that he can buy additional computers to serve more customers. Please help him by financing this loan. Thank you!

loans.use: Buy additional computers

loans.name: Ndyeye Fatou

texts.fr: Ndeye Fatou K. est une marchande de produits cosmétiques.  Elle exercice ce commerce depuis trois ans.  Elle est célibataire.  Avec ce commerce, elle nourrit sa mère veuve.  C’est le premier crédit qu’elle a sollicité auprès de l’IMCEC, et il va lui permettre d’acheter une toiture pour leur maison et elle compte rembourser avec son commerce.
texts.en:
Ndeye Fatou K. is single and has been selling cosmetics for three years. With her business, she provides for her mother who is a widow. This is the first loan she's seeking from Kiva's partner IMCEC, and she intends to use it to buy a new roof for their home. She will repay the loan with the profits of her business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new roof

loans.name: Sobia Ashiq Masih Group

texts.en:
Sobia baji is 31 years old married lady and a citizen of a city named Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. Sobia baji completed her education up until the 5th standard because her parents couldn’t afford her education expenses. Sobia baji got married to a man whose name is A. M. and he works for a utensils selling business. He sells different kinds of utensils (steal, plastic and glass). He buys utensils from different markets of Lahore and sells them to earn income. Sobia baji is the mother of two daughters. Both of her daughters are not of school going age. Sobia baji operates a sewing clothes business. She saves her income in a committee because she wants to utilize her committee amount for her daughter’s education. Sobia baji successfully repaid her prior two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). She is now applying for a new loan to buy more utensils to expand her husband’s utensil selling business.

Sobia baji is the group leader of another four women from her locality. Venus begum baji and Shabana yasmeen baji each are requesting a loan to buy iron to sell. Saba baji is requesting a loan to buy leather to sell. Talat yasmeen baji is requesting a loan to buy mobile phones for her mobile phones selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one each others loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy utensils to sell.

loans.name: Parveen Sadiq Mashi Group

texts.en:
My name is Parveen and I’m a 46-year-old widow. I live in Lahore which famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. I’m a mother of two kids: one son and one daughter. My son works in an iron business where he uses iron for making iron rods. My daughter is 14 years old and she studied in the 7th standard. When my husband died, my daughter quit her studies but I and my son motivated her to study further. I work in a clothes selling business. I buy clothes from the famous markets of Lahore such as “Azam Market & Ichra” and sell in the community to my neighbors. I have successfully repaid my two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy iron to expand my son’s iron rods making business.

I am the group leader of four other women from my locality. Nargis Baji and Ashi Baji each want a loan to buy iron to sell. Akbari Baji wants a loan to buy leather to sell. Asma Baji wants a loan to buy electric supplies (wires, switch boards and switches) to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy iron for making iron rods to sell

loans.name: Bassira

texts.fr: Bassira L. est un vigile qui habite aux Parcelles assainis de Thiès.   Il est célibataire mais il vit avec ses parents.  Il sollicite ce prêt pour acheter du ciment et du sable pour la réfection de leur maison et aussi d’acheter des poussins et des aliments pour son agriculture.  Monsieur L. a déjà reçu deux crédits auprès de l’IMCEC et il les a bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Bassira L. is a security guard who lives in the Parcelles Assainis of Thiès. He is unmarried but lives with his parents. He’s requesting this loan to buy cement and sand for repairing their house and also to buy chicks and feed for his farming. He has already received two loans before from IMCEC, and he repaid them.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repairing his house

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana A. is twenty-four years old. She is single and lives alone in a rented apartment in Nkawkaw in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works to make some income to improve herself.

Juliana is a food vendor. She cooks and sells rice and stew. She sells to the school pupils in the local school compound. She procures bags of rice and other ingredients such as vegetables, cooking oil, etc. from the local wholesalers. She also sells on a table top by the roadside in the evenings. Juliana has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk. She aspires to make some savings before marriage.

loans.use: To procure bags of rice

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas is 36 years old, a foodstuffs seller married with a child. She has been in this business for 5 years. She lives in  Lagos State, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of N 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Nasira Tariq Hussain Group

texts.en:
My name is Nasira and I am a citizen of a city called Lahore, which is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. My husband's name is T. H. and he runs a tea stall in the food market. He has a good number of customers. He has been in this profession for the last 5 years.

I am a mother of six girls. My first two daughters weave carpets. The others are enrolled in a school and are getting educated. I help my daughters in their carpet weaving business. We complete a carpet in 1 month and than we sell it to the carpet shop and earn a good income.

I have successfully repaid my two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I’m applying again for a loan to buy supplies (tea, sugar and milk) for my husband’s tea stall.

I’m the group leader of four other women from my locality. Razia baji wants a loan to buy school bags to sell. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy vehicles' spare parts to sell. Irshad baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business. Asia baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy supplies for tea stall

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa A. is 47 years old. She is a married mother of five children. Currently, three of her children are in school, in senior high and junior high. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Nkawkaw in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Her husband is a farmer. Adwoa works to make some income to support her husband financially in providing for the family.

Adwoa trades in food items such as tin tomatoes, fish, rice, pepper, etc., on a tabletop in the market square. She procures her products from wholesalers in the nearby towns at cost-effective prices. Adwoa sells the products mostly to food vendors in her community. She has been in business for 10 years.

She wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to maximize her profit margin. Adwoa aspires to improve upon her living standard and to support her children’s education.

loans.use: To procure food items

loans.name: Razia Rahmat Group

texts.en:
My name is Razia and I’m a 43 year old widow. It has been 15 years since my husband died of a heart attack. I am a mother of five boys. My eldest son has an iron selling business. He has five years of experience in the business. My second eldest son works in a factory on a monthly wage and the other three boys do not work. I work as a seamstress to serve my family. At first, I stitched clothes for my neighbors. After awhile, I also received orders from my relatives. Through this work I have been able to renovate my house and invest some money in my son's iron selling business. I am applying for a loan to buy iron for my son’s iron selling business. 

I am the group leader of four other women from my locality. Rukhsana baji and Nazia baji each want a loan to buy iron to sell. Tahira baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell, while Riffat baji wants a loan to buy electric supplies (wires, switch boards and switches) to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy iron to sell

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys T. is 50 years old. She is married and the mother of three children. According to her, one of her children has completed university. The rest are in senior high and junior high schools. She lives with her children and husband in a family house in Nkawkaw, in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She says though her husband is employed, she still needs to work hard to help herself and the family.

She sells provisions. Gladys sells in a shop at the market square. She procures products such as milk, sugar, bread, canned foods, etc., from wholesalers in Kumasi. Gladys has been in business for 30 years. She wants a loan to procure provisions in bulk. Gladys aspires to give her last two children the best education.

loans.use: To procure provisions

loans.name: Afusat

texts.en: Afusat sells  bags of charcoal. She is 52 years old and married with five children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. Afusat has been in this business for long. She hopes for the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Azra M. Hussain Group

texts.en:
'My name is Azra and I’m a 39-year-old married lady. I have been a citizen of Lahore, Pakistan, for the past 16 years. My husband's name is M. H.. He works in a factory for a monthly wage. I am a mother of seven kids: four daughters and three sons. My first three daughters prepare embroidered dresses. My elder son is involved in a dairy business. The others are getting education from a local school. I help my daughters in preparing embroidered clothes. I have successfully repaid my first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand my sons’ dairy business.'

Azra is the group leader of six other women from her locality. Razia baji and Qubra baji each want a loan to buy iron to sell. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit-selling business. Azran baji and Razia baji each want a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Parveen akhtar baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for her son's dairy business

loans.name: Abdusattor

texts.ru: Эрсалиев Абдусаттор житель района Абдурахмони Джоми. Женат и имеет восьмерых детей. Уже 27 лет работает в сфере животноводства. Занимается купле-продажей крупно-рогатого скота. Покупает молодых бычков , откармливает около 40 дней , а затем продает на тех же рынках. Кроме этого занимается сельским хозяйством. Но получаемый урожай использует для собственного потребления. Планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы купить еще одного бычка. Погасить кредит сможет в течение шести месяцев.
texts.en:
Abdusattor E. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He is married and has eight children. He has been working in the animal husbandry field for 27 years. He buys and sells cattle. He buys young calves, feeds them for about 40 days and then resells on the same markets. Besides that he is also in agriculture, but he keeps the produced harvest for himself. He plans to get a loan to buy one more calf. He can pay off the loan within six months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase head count of cattle

loans.name: Mosharif

texts.ru: Тухтошева Мошариф проживает в городе Яван. Возраст 42 года, замужем и имеет четверых детей. вместе с мужем занимается земледелием. Арендуют один га. земли , которы 50\50 засеивает картофелем и луком. Земля уже засеиная , но пришло время обробатывать землю , поэтому она решила получить кредит и использовать на покупку удобрений. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mosharif T. lives in the town of Yavan. She is 42 years old, married and has four children. She and her husband are in agriculture. They are renting one 1 ha. (hectare) of land half of which they sow with potatoes and other half with onions. Their land is already sown, but now is the time to fertilize the land and this is why Mosharif decided to get a loan and use it to buy fertilizer. She can pay off the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Shalon

texts.en: Shalon is 36 years old and married. She sells frozen food and drinks at Adewale Badajor Street, Field Bus Stop Igbo-Elerin, Lagos State, Nigeria. She needs a loan of NGN70, 000 to purchase more frozen food and drinks to sell in order to meet customer demand. She says a big 'thank you' to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen food and drink to sell

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en: Kehinde F. is a hair stylist who also sells hair extensions and hair creams. He is 40 years old and married with two children. He lives in Ballo Alaka Street, Church Bus Stop, Lagos State, Nigeria and has been in business since 2004. Kehinde would like to sell hair extensions and hair creams wholesale. He needs a loan of NGN100, 000 to purchase more hair extensions and creams to sell in order to meet customer demand. He says a big 'thank you' to LAPO Microfinance and Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and hair creams to sell

loans.name: Adijatu

texts.en: Adijatu is a firewood seller. She is 52 years old and married with four children. She lives in Oluwalogbo Street, Okoko Last Bus Stop, Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been in this trade for 30 years. She needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more firewood to sell so as to meet the demand of her customers. Adijaju says a big thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Shoyoye

texts.en: Shoyoye does fish pond farming; he is 40 years old and married with 4 children. He lives in Jelili Musa Close, Lagos State, Nigeria. He wants to expand his fish pond, so he needs the loan amount of N 60,000 to purchase more fingerlings and feed for the fish. Shoyoye says thanks to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more fingerlings and feed

loans.name: Fahriddin

texts.ru: Тохиров Фахриддин проживает в городе Яван. Живет в одном из отдаленных кишлаков . Занимается земледелием. Имеет 1 га . земли  . В данный момент не может засеить. Поэтому он планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы закупить семена лука и удобрения. Кредит поможет ему своевременно посееть лук и не остаться без урожая. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 10 месяцев.Фахриддину 33 года , он женат и имеет троих детей.
texts.en:
Fahriddin T. lives in the town of Yavan. He lives in one of the remote villages (kishlaks). He is in agriculture. He has one ha. (hectare) of land. He cannot sow the land at this time and this is why he plans to take out a loan to buy seeds of onions and fertilizer. The loan will help him sow the onions on time and not be left out without a harvest. He can pay off the loan within 10 months. Fahriddin is 33 years old, married and has three children.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Nickel

texts.en: Nickel is a fashion designer; she is 36 years old and married with a child. She sells cloth, tailoring materials and drinks. She has been in this business for over 15 years. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more cloth, tailoring materials, and drinks to sell and a weaving machine for sewing. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cloth and a weaving machine for sewing

loans.name: Marthe

texts.en: Marthe is 37 years old and married with 7 children. She lives in Banire Close, Lagos State, Nigeria where she sells foodstuffs, and she has been in business for 15 years. She needs the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. Marthe says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Olambek

texts.ru: Джаборов Оламбек житель города Яван. Возраст 29 лет, женат и имеет двоих детей. Занимается земледелием. Засеивает бахчевые. Подготавливает землю к посеву. Обратился за кредитом для того, чтобы закупить семена арбузов и дынь , а так же для покупки удобрений. Это даст возможность своевременно засеить землю и получить качественный урожай. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Olambek J. is a Yavan resident. He is 29 years old, married, and has two children. A farmer, he raises melons and gourds and is currently preparing the ground for planting. The loan is needed for buying watermelon and cantaloupe seeds, and also for fertilizer. With this help he will be able to plant at the right time, and reach a high quality harvest. The loan will be repaid over 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Seed and fertilizer purchase

loans.name: Waziran M. Rafiq Group

texts.en:
Waziran baji is 52 years old and a married lady and citizen of a city named Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is married to a man whose name is M. R., and he has a dairy business. He has a buffalo and Waziran baji also helps him in getting milk from her and selling it to the milk shops. She has three sons. Her eldest son works in a factory on monthly wage. The others are not employed and don’t do anything. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand her husband’s dairy business.
